symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by recurrent, unwanted thoughts (obsessions) and/or repetitive behaviors (compulsions).

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: A bleeding disorder caused by low levels of clotting protein in the blood, which can lead to heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia).

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myelogenous Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the bone marrow and blood, leading to an increase in white blood cells, including basophils.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Hemorrhagic Telangiectasia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that leads to abnormal blood vessel formation (arteriovenous malformations) throughout the body.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A blood disorder that results in an abnormal increase in blood cells, including basophils, which can sometimes be associated with itching (dermatographism).

diagnoses.name: Urticaria
diagnoses.description: Also known as hives, a condition marked by red, itchy welts on the skin, often related to dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by a persistently high count of eosinophils, a type of white blood cell, that can occasionally lead to a high basophil count.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder caused by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and other organs, which can cause symptoms similar to dermatographism.

diagnoses.name: Essential Thrombocythemia
diagnoses.description: A rare chronic blood disorder characterized by the overproduction of platelets by the bone marrow, which can lead to abnormal clotting or bleeding such as menorrhagia.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by feelings of worry, anxiety, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with one’s daily activities. It can sometimes present with obsessive-compulsive behaviors.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity reactions
diagnoses.description: An exaggerated immune response to a foreign substance, which can include allergens. This category can encompass conditions like Kounis syndrome, where an allergic reaction contributes to acute coronary syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder characterized by sudden episodes of swelling (angioedema). The swelling can occur in the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway, potentially leading to life-threatening breathing difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly. Symptoms can include angioedema, hives, difficulty breathing, and a significant drop in blood pressure.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by recurrent, unprovoked seizures. It is included due to the symptom of seizure disorders.

diagnoses.name: Mastocytosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by the accumulation of mast cells in the skin and/or internal organs. It can cause a variety of symptoms, including skin lesions, abdominal discomfort, and anaphylaxis-like symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Vascular Ehlers-Danlos syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic connective tissue disorder that can cause vascular anomalies, spontaneous vessel rupture, and skin and tissue fragility. It is characterized by symptoms such as easy bruising, thin skin, and a characteristic facial appearance.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Commonly caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), it can lead to fever, sore throat, fatigue, and lymphadenitis (swollen lymph nodes).

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body, including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs. Symptoms can vary widely but may include lymphadenopathy (swollen lymph nodes), rash, and joint pain.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in lymphocytes (a type of white blood cell). It can cause lymphadenopathy, fever, night sweats, weight loss, and increased risk of infections.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that causes tumors to form on nerve tissue. These tumors can develop anywhere in the nervous system, including the brain, spinal cord, and nerves. Neurofibromatosis can be associated with skin changes and bone deformities.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, it can cause onychodystrophy along with joint pain and swelling. Psoriatic arthritis can go along with systemic manifestations like fatigue that can indirectly affect memory and mood, leading to anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.description: Excessive thyroid hormone can lead to heat intolerance/hyperthermia, anxiety, and can contribute to onychodystrophy. Although less common, it could be associated with cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that leads to the increased production of red blood cells, polycythemia vera can directly cause polycythemia and has been associated with itching (pruritus), especially following a hot bath or shower. Patients may also report memory problems, anxiety, and a plethora of other symptoms due to increased blood viscosity.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic renal failure can result in a variety of dermatologic manifestations including onychodystrophy. It can also cause cognitive issues, anxiety, and tends to be associated with secondary polycythemia due to erythropoietin production from the damaged kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Wilson’s Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inherited disorder that causes copper to accumulate in your liver, brain, and other vital organs. Wilson's Disease can lead to neurological and psychiatric symptoms such as memory problems and anxiety, and might also cause onychodystrophy due to copper deposition in the nails.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: An iron overload disorder that could potentially lead to onychodystrophy. Patients can also exhibit diabetes (bronze diabetes), leading to elevated blood glucose levels that could, in turn, cause or worsen polyneuropathy, indirectly affecting memory. Anxiety can be a psychological symptom due to the overall health burden.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Though typically associated with cold intolerance, cases of hashitoxicosis or initial presentations of Graves' disease could present with hyperthermia. This condition can also cause cognitive difficulties, sometimes severe enough to mimic dementia, and is a common cause of onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect the skin, including the nails (onychodystrophy), and may contribute to neurological and psychological problems such as anxiety and cognitive impairment. Individuals might also experience a variety of other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: While primarily psychiatric in nature, severe anxiety can affect cognitive function, leading to perceived or mild memory problems. The stress associated with chronic anxiety can exacerbate other symptoms or conditions, indirectly affecting the body in multiple ways.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: Certain types of leukemia can cause onychodystrophy and polycythemia. Additionally, the systemic effects of leukemia, including hypermetabolism, can lead to hyperthermia. Neurological symptoms such as memory problems and anxiety can be secondary to either the disease itself or its treatment.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Lyme disease can cause migratory patchy macular erythema (erythema migrans), rashes, and sometimes systemic symptoms like laryngitis due to associated viral infections. Polycythemia and hypermobility are less directly associated but could be considered in complex presentations.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes
diagnoses.reasoning: While primarily identified by joint hypermobility, skin manifestations such as rashes and unusual patterns of erythema can occur. Ehlers-Danlos syndromes do not typically cause polycythemia or laryngitis directly, but systemic involvement or associated conditions could explain a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.reasoning: Psoriasis can lead to widespread rashes and is associated with systemic inflammatory symptoms that could potentially explain migratory erythema. It is less directly associated with polycythemia, laryngitis, or hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reasoning: Characterized by skin rashes and muscle weakness, dermatomyositis might show skin manifestations similar to migratory patchy macular erythema. It often involves systemic symptoms, potentially linking to laryngitis but less so to polycythemia or hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: SLE can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin rashes and potential blood abnormalities like polycythemia in response to chronic inflammation. It can also lead to non-specific symptoms such as laryngitis. Joint symptoms are common but would not typically be classified as hypermobility.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: An inflammatory condition that can cause rashes, fever, and a variety of systemic symptoms. Migratory rash and erythema are common, and while it might cause systemic symptoms similar to those of laryngitis, polycythemia, and hypermobility are less common associations.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.reasoning: MCAS can cause a variety of symptoms including rashes, laryngitis due to throat swelling, and potentially polycythemia if there is an associated condition. Hypermobility is also seen in a subset of patients with MCAS, often co-occurring with Ehlers-Danlos Syndromes.

diagnoses.name: Schnitzler's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare condition characterized by chronic urticaria (hives), which can resemble rashes, and a monoclonal gammopathy. It can involve systemic symptoms that might mimic those of laryngitis, but polycythemia and hypermobility are not direct features.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reasoning: A type of blood cancer that leads to polycythemia. While it primarily affects blood cell production, itching after bathing (aquagenic pruritus) and erythromelalgia can be associated skin manifestations. Direct connections to laryngitis and hypermobility are less common.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.reasoning: This tick-borne disease causes a distinct spotted rash that could be thought of as patchy macular erythema, fever, and potentially symptoms that mimic laryngitis. It's less likely to cause polycythemia and hypermobility.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by visual disturbances and other aura symptoms followed by a severe headache, often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms may include weakness on one side of the body, trouble speaking, dizziness, and loss of balance or coordination.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to symptoms such as ataxia, weakness, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: An abnormal growth of cells within the brain, which can be benign or malignant. Symptoms can include headache, nausea, balance and coordination problems, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from inadequate blood flow through the posterior circulation of the brain, causing symptoms such as dizziness, double vision, ataxia, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It often includes sudden weakness, confusion, balance issues, and headache but without lasting effects.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance, loss of consciousness, or convulsions, associated with abnormal electrical activity in the brain.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Cerebellar Degeneration
diagnoses.description: A process where the cerebellum of the brain deteriorates, leading to problems with balance, movement, and coordination.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, caused by infection or an autoimmune response. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, and sometimes seizures and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can cause severe head pain, nausea, sensitivity to light or sound, and sometimes numbness or weakness.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A stroke occurs when blood flow to a part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, causing symptoms such as numbness or weakness, especially on one side of the body, and severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Multiple Sclerosis is a disease of the central nervous system marked by numbness or weakness, coordination and balance issues, and in some cases, a headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, it presents with temporary symptoms of numbness, weakness, and a possible sudden, severe headache.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: A condition of chronic nerve damage due to diabetes, causing numbness, weakness, and sometimes pain in the hands, arms, feet, and legs.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A brain tumor can cause symptoms depending on its location, including headaches, numbness, weakness, and changes in cognitive or physical functions.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: This condition results from damage to peripheral nerves and often causes weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in the hands and feet.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder where the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to muscle weakness and numbness that usually begins in the feet and legs and may spread to the upper body and arms.

diagnoses.name: Hypoglycemia
diagnoses.details: Low blood sugar levels can lead to symptoms including headache, numbness of the mouth, weakness, and shaking.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: Caused by a tick bite, Lyme disease can present at its early stage with a headache, weakness, and numbness or tingling in the extremities.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Rheumatoid arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Hepatitis B or C with Cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can cause a broad range of symptoms including skin manifestations (like postinflammatory dyspigmentation and telangiectasias), leukopenia, and kidney involvement leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by muscle weakness and skin changes, including postinflammatory dyspigmentation and telangiectasias. Renal involvement might be less common but can manifest as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma (Systemic Sclerosis)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease often presents with skin changes including telangiectasias and postinflammatory dyspigmentation, and can also affect internal organs, presenting with features such as proteinuria due to kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This condition combines features of several diseases including SLE, dermatomyositis, and scleroderma, presenting with symptoms such as leukopenia, proteinuria, and skin manifestations like telangiectasias.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily affecting joints, it can present with systemic symptoms including leukopenia. Skin manifestations and renal involvement (proteinuria) are less common but possible in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily about the kidneys and characterized by proteinuria, associated conditions or complications can include skin changes and blood abnormalities like leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Porphyria Cutanea Tarda
diagnoses.rationale: A type of porphyria that leads to skin manifestations such as postinflammatory dyspigmentation and fragility, notably with blisters that heal with scarring and pigmentation. While telangiectasias are common, leukopenia and proteinuria are less directly associated but can occur in complications.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV can cause leukopenia due to its impact on the immune system. Proteinuria may indicate HIV-associated nephropathy. Skin manifestations could be secondary to infections or inflammatory conditions in HIV-positive patients.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: In its late stages, Lyme disease can have diverse manifestations including skin changes. Leukopenia and proteinuria are less commonly associated but can appear in complex cases or when the disease affects the kidneys.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Various forms of vasculitis could lead to skin manifestations (like telangiectasias), kidney disease (manifesting as proteinuria), and blood disorders (like leukopenia), depending on the type and severity of the vasculitis.
